#Text=Colard Mansion
#Text=Page from the Ovide Moralisé , with woodcut and added illumination ( Bruges , Public Library , Inc. 3877 , f. 294v ) .
#Text=Colard Mansion ( or Colart , before 1440 – after May 1484 ) was a 15th-century Flemish scribe and printer who worked together with William Caxton .
#Text=He is known as the first printer of a book with copper engravings , and as the printer of the first books in English and French .
#Text=Biography
#Text=Colard
#Text=Mansion was a central figure in the early printing industry in Bruges .

#Text=He was active as early as 1454 as a bookseller , and was also active as a scribe , translator and contractor for manuscripts , which meant entering into contracts with the clients , and organizing and sub-contracting the elements such as scribing , decorating and binding . [ 1 ]
#Text=From 1474 until 1476 he worked together with the early English printer William Caxton , and he continued the company on his own afterwards .
#Text=Caxton probably learned the art of printing from Mansion , [ 2 ]
#Text=and it was from Mansion 's press that the first books printed in English ( Recuyell of the Historyes of Troye ) and French came . [ 3 ]
#Text=He moved to the Burg , the commercial heart of Bruges at the time , in 1478 .
#Text=Mansion suffered heavily under the economic crisis in Bruges in the 1480s , and only one work was printed after the death of Mary of Burgundy in 1482 .
#Text=Nothing is known with certainty about his life after 1484 , although he may have moved to Picardy .
#Text=Work

#Text=Mansion sold illuminated manuscripts to the aristocracy , and luxurious incunabula to the bourgeoisie , but he was one of the first to also publish smaller and cheaper books of only twenty to thirty pages , mainly in French .
#Text=Nowadays , 25 editions of incunabula by Mansion alone are known , making him the most prolific of Bruges ' early printers .
#Text=Only two of these are in Latin , all others are in French , many of them first editions .
#Text=Customers of Mansion include Charles de Croÿ , prince of Chimay , and Marie , the widow of Louis de Luxembourg , Count of Saint-Pol .
#Text=Mansion has been called the first printer of luxury books . [ 4 ]
#Text=He collaborated with major manuscript illuminators , such as the Master of the Dresden Prayer Book , who were fast losing work to printing , or copyists of their work .

#Text=In fact only two of his books are illustrated , the influential Ovide Moralisé with woodcuts , and a French translation of Boccaccio 's De Casibus Virorum Illustrium , the first book to be illustrated with engravings , some of which have been claimed to be the work of the Dresden Prayer Book Master and other identified illuminators in the circle of the Master of Anthony of Burgundy .
#Text=As intaglio prints , the nine engravings had to be printed separately from the relief text and then pasted in , and only three copies are known with the engravings .
#Text=More copies are known without the engravings , several of which contain illuminations instead .

#Text=It has been suggested that this was Mansion 's original intention ( other incunabula left spaces for manual illustration ) , but that this hybrid product did not attract the wealthy buyers of illuminations , so the engravings were an afterthought , aimed at a less exclusive market . [ 5 ]
#Text=Mansion is also known as the translator of at least five texts from Latin to French , including Le dialogue des créatures , printed by Dutch Gerard Leeu in 1482 .
#Text=Known works
#Text=Woodcut from the Ovide Moralisé illustrating Mars ( Bruges , Public Library , Inc. 3877 , f. 9r )
#Text=1467 : Romuleon ( manuscript by Benvenuto Rambaldi da Imola , translated by Jean Miélot , dedicated to Philip the Good [ 6 ]
#Text=1472 or later : Penitence d'Adam ( Testament of Adam ) ( manuscript ) , dedicated to Lewis de Bruges [ 6 ]
#Text=1474-1475 : Recuyell of the Historyes of Troye , together with William Caxton and Johann Veldener
#Text=1475 : The Game and Playe of Chesse , together with Caxton ( who translated it from the French version ) , based on a work by Jacobus de Cessolis
#Text=1476 : Le Jardin de dévotion by Petrus de Alliaco , Mansion 's first book as an independent publisher [ 7 ]

#Text=1476 : De cas de nobles hommes et femmes ( De Casibus Virorum Illustrium ) by Giovanni Boccaccio , [ 8 ] translated into French by Laurent Premierfait , was the first book to be illustrated with engravings , [ 9 ] probably made by Marc le Bongeteur .
#Text=1476 : Controversie de Noblesse by Buonaccorso da Montemagno ( or Surse de Pistoye ) , translated into French by Jean Miélot
#Text=1476-1477 : an anonymous French prediction text
#Text=1477 : La consolation de la philosophie by Boethius
#Text=1477 : Estrif de Fortune et de Vertu ( anonymous ) [ 6 ]
#Text=1477 : Traité de l’espere , French translation of the Tractatus de Origine , Natura , Jure et Mutationibus Monetarum by Nicole Oresme in 26 chapters [ 10 ]
#Text=1479 : Le quadriloque invectif by Alain Chartier
#Text=La somme rurale by Jean Boutillier

#Text=1479 : Opera : De caelesti hyerarchia . De ecclesiastica hyerarchia . De divinis nominibus . De mystica theologia . Epistolae , a complete edition in Latin of the works of Pseudo-Dionysius the Areopagite , translated by Ambrosio Traversari
#Text=1480 : Art de bien mourir ( anonymous )
#Text=1480 ? : Guillaume Caoursin , Rhodiae Obsidionis descriptio [ 11 ]
#Text=before June 1481 : Valere Maxime ( life of Saint Hubert ) , dedicated to Philippe de Hornes [ 6 ]
#Text=1482 : Dyalogue des creatures , translated by Mansion from the Latin Dialogus creaturarum [ 6 ]
#Text=1484 : Ovide moralisé , first edition of Ovid 's Metamorphoses , illustrated with woodcuts , rearranged and partly rewritten by Mansion himself , published in May 1484 . [ 12 ]
#Text=It is his last known work , and it has been speculated that the expensive book bankrupted the company .
#Text=This book was reprinted as the Bible des poëtes ( Poets ' Bible ) at least four times in Paris between 1493 and 1531 .

#Text=Afterwards , a purer version ( with all allegorical additions by Mansion removed , but keeping his translations ) under the title Grand Olympe des histoires poëtiques du Prince de poësie Ovide Naso en sa Metamorphose was published repeatedly between 1532 and 1570 .
#Text=Unknown date :
#Text=the Distichs of Cato
#Text=Les Evangiles des quenouilles ( anonymous , circa 1480 )
#Text=La doctrine de bien vivre en ce monde ( also called Donat espirituel ) by Jean Gerson
#Text=La Danse des aveugles
#Text=by Pierre Michault , secretary of Charles the Bold
#Text=Invectives contre la secte de Vauderie
#Text=Adevineaux amoureux ( anonymous ) . [ 6 ]
#Text=Incunabula by Mansion are scattered throughout collections mainly in Western Europe .
#Text=The largest such collection is in Paris , and the 16 copies of 10 different titles in the Public Library of Bruges form the second biggest collection . [ 13 ]
